title: The Mark of Judgment
shortSummary: Ezekiel 9 depicts a divine judgment on Jerusalem where six men with weapons are commanded to execute God's wrath, while a man clothed in linen marks those who mourn over the city's sins for protection. This chapter highlights God's righteous judgment against pervasive sin and His mercy toward those who repent and grieve over iniquity.
timeline: c. 593 BC - During the Babylonian siege of Jerusalem, prior to the city's destruction

keyCharacters.name: Ezekiel
keyCharacters.description: The prophet receiving the vision and interceding in prayer as he witnesses God's judgment on Jerusalem.

keyCharacters.name: Man clothed with linen
keyCharacters.description: A heavenly figure tasked with marking the foreheads of the faithful who mourn the city's abominations, symbolizing divine protection.

keyCharacters.name: Six men with slaughter weapons
keyCharacters.description: Agents of God's judgment who carry out the execution of the wicked in Jerusalem without mercy.

definitions.definition: A small container for ink, symbolizing the act of marking or writing, used here to mark the foreheads of the righteous.
A sign placed on the foreheads of those who mourn sin, indicating God's protection from judgment.
A heavenly being associated with God's presence; here, the glory of God moves from the cherub at the temple threshold.
Detestable sins or actions that provoke God's wrath, often idolatry or moral corruption in the biblical context.

outline.heading: The Command to Prepare for Judgment
outline.description: God commands the men with weapons to prepare for execution, introducing the man clothed in linen who will mark the faithful, setting the stage for divine judgment.

outline.heading: The Glory of God Departs and the Mark is Given
outline.description: The glory of God moves from the temple threshold, signaling impending judgment, and the man clothed in linen is instructed to mark those who mourn Jerusalem’s sins.

outline.heading: The Execution of Judgment Begins
outline.description: The six men with weapons are commanded to slay without pity, sparing only those with the mark, emphasizing God's righteous and impartial judgment.

outline.heading: Ezekiel’s Intercession and God’s Response
outline.description: Ezekiel pleads for mercy on the remnant, but God declares the iniquity of Israel and Judah is great and that judgment will be executed without pity.

outline.heading: The Report of Obedience
outline.description: The man clothed with linen reports that he has completed the task as commanded, confirming the fulfillment of God's judgment.

application: Recognize the seriousness of sin and the certainty of God's righteous judgment, motivating repentance and godly sorrow.
Trust in God's mercy and protection for those who mourn and turn from sin, as symbolized by the mark on the forehead.
Pray earnestly for the spiritual welfare of others, interceding like Ezekiel for those facing judgment.
Obey God's commands promptly and faithfully, as demonstrated by the man clothed in linen who carried out God's instructions exactly.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD said unto him, Go through the midst of the city, through the midst of Jerusalem, and set a mark upon the foreheads of the men that sigh and that cry for all the abominations that be done in the midst thereof.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's mercy in marking and protecting those who grieve over sin, showing that genuine repentance is recognized by God.

keyVerses.text: Slay utterly old and young, both maids, and little children, and women: but come not near any man upon whom is the mark; and begin at my sanctuary. Then they began at the ancient men which were before the house.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the severity of God's judgment and the impartiality of His justice, beginning with the leaders responsible for the nation's sin.

keyVerses.text: Then said he unto me, The iniquity of the house of Israel and Judah is exceeding great, and the land is full of blood, and the city full of perverseness: for they say, The LORD hath forsaken the earth, and the LORD seeth not.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals the depth of Israel's sin and their false belief that God is indifferent, justifying the coming judgment.
